event.summary: 07/27/1993: Three bombs exploded overnight in Milan and Rome. In this second incident a car bomb exploded by the 17th century Church of St. John the Lateran in Rome. The "Armed Phalange," claimed responsibility.
event.corp1: Church of St. John the Lateran
event.target1: Church of St. John the Lateran in Rome
event.motive: The perpetrators were demanding political reform in light of the nation's massive corruption scandal
event.propcomment: The explosion damaged an obelisk and part of the rear of the basilica.
event.addnotes: Police discounted the "Armed Phalange" as a real force, pointing out that the organization, if it really exists, only calls in after terrorist acts have been reported by the media. This case was one of three related attacks (cf. 1993072701;1993072703)
event.scite1: Charles Ridley, “Car Bombs in Rome and Milan Kill Five, Wound at least 32,” United Press International, July 27, 1993.
event.scite2: “Mystery of Car Bombings Deepen,” Hobart Mercury, July, 30, 1993.
event.scite3: “Terror Bomb Blasts Kill Five, Wound 29, Agence France Presse, July 28, 1993.
